title: Community effects in regulation of translation
abstract: Certain forms of translational regulation, and translation itself, rely on long-range interactions between proteins bound to the different ends of mRNAs. A widespread assumption is that such interactions occur only in <italic>cis</italic>, between the two ends of a single transcript. However, certain translational regulatory defects of the <italic>Drosophila oskar (osk)</italic> mRNA can be rescued in <italic>trans</italic>. We proposed that inter-transcript interactions, promoted by assembly of the mRNAs in particles, allow regulatory elements to act in <italic>trans</italic>. Here we confirm predictions of that model and show that disruption of PTB-dependent particle assembly inhibits rescue in <italic>trans</italic>. Communication between transcripts is not limited to different <italic>osk</italic> mRNAs, as regulation imposed by <italic>cis</italic>-acting elements embedded in the <italic>osk</italic> mRNA spreads to <italic>gurken</italic> mRNA. We conclude that community effects exist in translational regulation.
